column4: while i like LXDE very much, i find that it's still a bit rough around the edges, being a relatively newer desktop environment...i would consider Xfce to be more refined
Wheres its downfall?
LXDE's or Xfce's?

the biggest issue i've been having is that PCManFM (the file browser) crashes sometimes, including sometimes during a file transfer (i've stopped copying big files with it), and sometimes it doesn't automatically reload afterwards (which is bad because it's what gives you the desktop, after all...but you can reload it manually with: pcmanfm --desktop )
Thanks for the heads up *writes down command*

the second most annoying thing i've experienced is that sometimes the volume control applet in the notification area doesn't respond to being clicked ...but i don't think a lot of users experience that problem
do you mean with file:/// ?

Not sure what you mean? If I open up a folder on my desktop I can see 'mac data' etc which are hosted on a windows server in the office. But when attaching files via chrome or ff I can only see local files?
oh i see
Bit of a pain that I need to copy files to my desktop first before I can attach them or vice-versa..

yeah i think there is a bug reported for this ...anyway, you *should* be able to access your network drives, they're just not mounted in the same place as your local drives (when they are mounted by Nautilus / PCManFM)
there is a .gvfs folder in your home folder, you can see if your network drives are accessible inside there
you need to show hidden files (Ctrl+H) to see it
Yeah I'm in. I can see 'mac data' in it - Which is what I want to see in chrome.
Ah, so I'll need to go in via chrome to home/.gvfs
yes, that will probably work
but the other thing to consider is that some websites where you upload files (e.g., Gmail) let you just drag the file icon into the web page
so you can drag it from the file browser (Nautilus in Ubuntu ...PCManFM in Lubuntu)

this is *a* bug report for this problem, but i'm not sure it's the one i was thinking of, which i recall was not specific to Chrome/Chromium (and it shouldn't necessarily be, because individual applications *shouldn't* have to do the work themselves of showing gvfs mounts with other mounts): https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/chromium-browser/+bug/796689
Thanks! :). I've just bookedmarked .gvfs in my chrome file browser. Seems to have stuck.
cool, i'm glad you got a solution that works for you

personally (though for unrelated reasons, mostly so they can be accessed by multiple user accounts in the same place and survive logging in and out and can be mounted and unmounted easily from the command-line including remotely via SSH), i just "hard-mount" my network shares, for example: sudo smbmount //Del/Beltrami /media/Beltrami -o user=ek
